articles.headline: Compromise at the Supreme Court Veils Its Rifts
articles.snippet: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. managed to shepherd the justices together, but the 9-to-0 decisions often masked deep disagreements.
articles.abstract: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. managed to shepherd the justices together, but the 9-to-0 decisions often masked deep disagreements.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two very different group portraits of the Supreme Court emerged this term, one familiar and one unexpected.

articles.headline: U.S. Accuses T-Mobile of Overbilling
articles.snippet: The Federal Trade Commission said the carrier made hundreds of millions of dollars from premium texting services that consumers never ordered.
articles.abstract: The Federal Trade Commission said the carrier made hundreds of millions of dollars from premium texting services that consumers never ordered.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — T-Mobile, which sees itself as a new kind of carrier, now stands accused of an old-fashioned practice — overbilling its customers.
articles.byline: By Edward Wyatt and Brian X. Chen

articles.headline: China’s Hurdle to Fast Action on Climate Change
articles.snippet: The existential question in Beijing remains whether China can simultaneously cut carbon emissions while pursuing strong economic growth.
articles.abstract: The existential question in Beijing remains whether China can simultaneously cut carbon emissions while pursuing strong economic growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Environmental Protection Agency published in June its new rules to combat carbon emissions from power plants, the American political class lit up in debates over what this meant for the country’s carbon emissions, its coal industry and its economic growth.

articles.headline: Wild Ride by U.S. Comes to End, but Soccer Is the Winner
articles.snippet: The United States was eliminated from the World Cup by Belgium despite a memorable performance from goalkeeper Tim Howard.
articles.abstract: The United States was eliminated from the World Cup by Belgium despite a memorable performance from goalkeeper Tim Howard.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALVADOR, Brazil — It felt as if Tim Howard would never go down. As if the United States would never go down, standing there, taking shots like an undersize fighter clinging desperately to a puncher’s chance. Howard saved with his hands. His feet. His legs. His knees. At one point, Howard even had a shot bounce off the crest over his heart.

articles.headline: JPMorgan’s Jamie Dimon Has Throat Cancer That He Calls ‘Curable’
articles.snippet: In an email to the bank’s employees and shareholders, Mr. Dimon said that doctors discovered the cancer at an early stage.
articles.abstract: In an email to the bank’s employees and shareholders, Mr. Dimon said that doctors discovered the cancer at an early stage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, has throat cancer and will begin treatment shortly at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, he said in a note to the bank’s employees and shareholders late Tuesday.

articles.headline: Many Sharp Turns in Bergdahl’s Path to Army
articles.snippet: People who knew Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl in Idaho paint a fairly consistent portrait: hard-working and socially awkward, full of restless energy and romantic plans.
articles.abstract: People who knew Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl in Idaho paint a fairly consistent portrait: hard-working and socially awkward, full of restless energy and romantic plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: KETCHUM, Idaho — In 2003, the year he turned 17, Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl left his mark on the wet cement floor of the Strega Tea Bar Gallery and Cafe, a swirling design signed with a florid “B.” The drawing is a lasting statement that this liberal-tinctured ski resort town, where he took ballet and fencing lessons, met artists and debated philosophy, had become his second home.
articles.byline: By Kirk Johnson and Matt Furber

articles.headline: Twitter’s Revolving Door Spins Again
articles.snippet: The continuing turmoil in Twitter’s executive suite, a hallmark of the company’s eight-year existence, suggests that the company is struggling in the face of stiffening competition from Facebook.
articles.abstract: The continuing turmoil in Twitter’s executive suite, a hallmark of the company’s eight-year existence, suggests that the company is struggling in the face of stiffening competition from Facebook.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter’s chief executive, Dick Costolo, has replaced virtually every crucial executive at the company in the last few months as he has struggled to figure out how to get more people using the service.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: After Retreat, Iraqi Soldiers Fault Officers
articles.snippet: When Iraq’s security forces crumbled in the face of militants, they were labeled cowards. But in the case of one brigade, at least, what emerges instead is a portrait of mismanagement and treachery.
articles.abstract: When Iraq’s security forces crumbled in the face of militants, they were labeled cowards. But in the case of one brigade, at least, what emerges instead is a portrait of mismanagement and treachery.
articles.lead_paragraph: AIN AL-TAMR, Iraq — The forlorn scenes in the ancient Al-Ukhaidir fortress tell of a government force in deep disarray. Flies circle beneath its high ceilings, above dozens of demoralized men who pass the day sleeping on dusty stone floors.

articles.headline: Arab Boy’s Death Escalates Clash Over Abductions
articles.snippet: In what may have been a retaliation for the kidnapping and killing of three Israeli teenagers who were buried a day earlier, a Palestinian youth was forced into a car and killed.
articles.abstract: In what may have been a retaliation for the kidnapping and killing of three Israeli teenagers who were buried a day earlier, a Palestinian youth was forced into a car and killed.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The abduction and killing of a Palestinian teenager whose burned body was found in a Jerusalem forest on Wednesday further poisoned relations between Israelis and Palestinians and prompted international outrage as the police investigated the death as a possible Israeli revenge killing.

articles.headline: To Hold Senate, Democrats Rely on Single Women
articles.snippet: Though they are strong supporters of the Democratic Party, they tend not to turn out in nonpresidential election years like this one.
articles.abstract: Though they are strong supporters of the Democratic Party, they tend not to turn out in nonpresidential election years like this one.
articles.lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — The decline of marriage over the last generation has helped create an emerging voting bloc of unmarried women that is profoundly reshaping the American electorate to the advantage, recent elections suggest, of the Democratic Party. What is far from clear is whether Democrats will benefit in the midterm contests this fall.
